title: Automated License Plate Readers (Hollister Police Department)

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Automated License Plate Readers (Hollister Police Department)
communications.communication:
Dear Custodian of Records:

This letter constitutes a request under the California Public Records Act ("CPRA") from the Electronic Frontier Foundation, submitted with the assistance of MuckRock News. 

We request the following records related to Automated License Plate Readers ("ALPRs") and your law enforcement agency ("Agency").

Part A - Information related to ALPR data sharing.

A1. The names of agencies and organizations with which the Agency shares ALPR data;
A2. The names of agencies and organizations from which the Agency receives ALPR data;
A3. The names of agencies and organizations with which the Agency shares “hot list” information;
A4. The names of agencies and organizations from which the Agency receives “hot list” information.
The information requested in items A1-A4 is readily available for extraction through the ALPR software you use. For example, with Vigilant Solutions/Motorola Solutions, this data can be exported easily using the Data Sharing Report function. With Flock Safety, this information is available through the transparency portal function. Other software, such as BOSS, has similar functionality.  

Most agencies have encountered little difficulty in providing this information (see below). In a small number of cases, an agency has interpreted items A1-A4 as requesting the creation of a record that does not exist. We disagree: this data is maintained by your software, can be exported through software your agency has already purchased, and is therefore subject to CPRA. 

However, should you disagree, you may alternatively produce the following records:  

A5. All agreements, memoranda of understanding, requests, or other certifying documents that external agencies have signed to comply with Sec 1798.90.52(b) for accessing your agency's ALPR data. These documents are also often required under the "Releasing ALPR Data" subsection of a California law enforcement agency's SB 34 policy. 
A6. All agreements, memoranda of understanding, requests, or other certifying documents  that your agency has signed pursuant to Sec 1798.90.52(b) to access other agencies' ALPR data.
A7. All "records of access" required by Sec. 1798.90.52(a) for the periods January 1, 2021 until the date of processing this request. 

Items A5-A7 are not necessary if your agency provides the information requested in items A1-A4. We feel that items A1-A4 are more focused and would require less labor from your agency to produce. 

Part B - Information Related to Numbers of “Detections” (plate scans) and “Hits” (plate scans that matched to a hotlist)

B1. The aggregate number of "detections" collected during 2021.
B2.  The aggregate number of “hits” during 2021.
B3. The aggregate number of "detections" from January 1, 2022 until the date this request is processed. If your agency has a retention period shorter than 1 year, please provide whatever data is available based on your retention period. For example, most Flock Safety systems may not have this data beyond 30 days. 
B4.  The aggregate number of “hits” from January 1, 2022 until the date this request is processed. If your agency has a retention period shorter than 1 year, please provide whatever data is available based on your retention period.

The information requested in items B1-B4 is readily available through the ALPR software you use. For example, with Vigilant Solutions/Motorola Solutions, this data can be exported easily using the Hit Ratio Report function. With Flock Safety, this information  is available through the transparency portal function. Other software, such as BOSS, has similar functionality.  As noted above, this information exists within your system and can be easily exported with existing software.

Part C - Assistance, Description, and Recommendations. 

We make the following requests under section 6253.1 of the California Public Records Act

C1. A description of  the information technology and physical location in which the records exist.
C2. Assist us identifying records and information that will help the public understand how ALPR data and hotlists are shared, how much data is collected year-to-year, and how much of that data matches a hot list; and 
C3. Provide suggestions for overcoming any practical basis for denying access to the information sought.

Please note that more than 80 California law enforcement agencies have provided the information requested in Parts A1-A4 and B1-B4 in previous years. For your reference we have included a list below with the names of the agencies that have historically provided these records. 

American Canyon Police Department
Auburn Police Department
Bakersfield Police Department
Beaumont Police Department
Bell Gardens Police Department
Bell Police Department
Belvedere Police Department
Beverly Hills Police Department
Brawley Police Department
Brentwood Police Department
Buena Park Police Department
Burbank Police Department
Carlsbad Police Department
Cathedral City Police Department
Chino Police Department
Chula Vista Police Department
Citrus Heights Police Department
Claremont Police Department
Clayton Police Department
Contra Costa County Sheriff's Office
Coronado Police Department
CSU Fullerton Police Department
Cypress Police Department
El Segundo Police Department
Fairfield Police Department
Folsom Police Department
Fontana Police Department
Fresno Police Department
Fullerton Police Department
Galt Police Department
Garden Grove Police Department
Gardena Police Department
Glendale Police Department
Hemet Police Department
Hermosa Beach Police Department
Imperial Police Department
Irvine Police Department
La Habra Police Department
La Mesa Police Department
La Verne Police Department
Laguna Beach Police Department
Livermore Police Department
Lodi Police Department
Long Beach Police Department
Marin County Sheriff's Office
Martinez Police Department
Merced Police Department
Mill Valley Police Department
Modesto Police Department
Monterey Park Police Department
Newport Beach Police Department
Oakley Police Department
Orange County Sheriff's Office
Orange Police Department
Palm Springs Police Department
Palos Verdes Estates Police
Pasadena Police Department
Pleasant Hill Police Department
Pomona Police Department
Redlands Police Department
Redondo Beach Police Department
Ripon Police Department
Roseville Police Department
Salinas Police Department
San Bernardino County Sheriff's Office
San Diego County Sheriff's Office
San Diego Police Department
San Mateo County Sheriff's Office
Sausalito Police Department
Simi Valley Police Department
Stanislaus County Sheriff's Office
Stockton Police Department
Tiburon Police Department
Torrance Police Department
Tracy Police Department
Tustin Police Department
West Sacramento Police Department
Westminster Police Department
Woodland Police Department
Yolo County Sheriff's Office
(This URL links to a dataset with links to the records: https://www.eff.org/document/data-driven-2-california-dragnet-data-set ) 

CPRA requires you to undertake reasonable efforts to locate responsive records and to work in good faith with requesters to respond to their request. See CYAC v. City of National City, 220 Cal.App.4th 1385, 1430 (2013). Thus under the CPRA you are obligated to conduct a reasonable search and cannot deny a request merely because it might generate a large volume of records. 

We ask that you please respond to this request within 10 days either by providing all the requested records or by providing a written response setting forth the legal authority on which you rely in withholding or redacting any document, as well as stating when documents will be made available. Should you choose to withhold or reject this request, we ask that you provide an explanation of why your agency is responding differently compared to the many others that have complied with our request. 

We also request that any records maintained in an electronic format be provided in that same format (such as a PDF, CSV or XLS file), to avoid copying costs.

However, should you be unable to do so, EFF will reimburse you for the direct costs of copying these records (if you elect to charge for copying) plus postage. If you anticipate that these costs will exceed $25.00, or that the time needed to copy the records will delay their release, please contact me so that I can arrange to inspect the documents or decide which documents I wish to have copied. Please also provide an invoice and a cost breakdown of the fee estimate. If the fees are less than $25.00, please copy and send the records and invoice as soon as possible, and we will promptly pay the required costs.

Thank you for your consideration of this request. If you have any questions or concerns, or if I can provide any clarification that will help identify responsive documents or focus this request, please do not hesitate to contact me at (415) 436-9333 x151 or dm@eff.org. You may also mail correspondence to the Electronic Frontier Foundation, 815 Eddy. St. San Francisco, CA, 94109.
                                               
Sincerely,
 
 
Dave Maass
Director of Investigations
Electronic Frontier Foundation

Regarding Part B of your request, the City has encountered technical difficulties in extracting the data sought and has reached out to the software vendor for assistance in compiling the requested reports. Regarding Part C of your request, the information you seek is located on the City's network, and is stored via the PlateSmart application. Note that the City does not share ALPR data nor hotlists. Thank you, ************************************************************************ Questions about your request? Reply to this email or sign in to contact staff at City of Hollister.

communications.communication:

The City has resolved the technical issues and is releasing the records related to previously provided information. Please note that the City has identified the following exemptions for redactions. Redactions have been applied to the records in accordance with Government Code section 7929.210, subdivision (a), and Government Code section 7922.000, as the release of such information would render the City’s information technology system vulnerable to potential attack and, therefore, the public interest served by not disclosing the information clearly outweighs the public interest served by disclosure. (Gov. Code, § 7929.210, subd., (a); Gov. Code, § 7322.000.) City Clerk, Jennifer Woodworth, is the party responsible for asserting the exemptions. This completes the City’s response to your records request, and we will consider this matter closed.  Thank you. * PRA 22-173 Documents for Production (01015200x7AD00).PDF ************************************************************************ Questions about your request? communications.subject: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: Village of Niles Employee Roster
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Illinois Freedom of Information Act., I hereby request the following records:

Documentation listing inactive employees of the Village of Niles including the reason why they are no longer an employee (resigned, retired, or terminated) along with their age, race, and gender between the dates of 01/01/2014 & the date this request is finally processed (inclusive of those dates).

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Niles Coalition

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Complaints filed online
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

All HIPAA and Civil Rights complaints filed online from January 1st 2019 until today's date ( 4/30/2020 ) as well as any documents related to such complaints (including, but not limited to, correspondence with either party, investigative notes, and OCR response letters).

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Dhruv Mehrotra

Dear Dhruv Mehrotra, I am writing in regard to your above referenced Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request dated: May 06, 2020.  I apologize for the delay in responding to your request as we have a backlog of files. 
I’m writing now to ask if you are still interested in pursuing your request.  Please let me know ASAP, but NLT November 17, 2022, whether you are.  If we have not heard from you by that date, we will assume you are no longer interested in pursuing your request and the file will be closed.

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: Kent School financial records
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

The following financial records for all schools under the authority of the school district:
- Acquaintance Roll (or salary and employment information by any other name)
- The Cash Book (or record of all financial transactions by any other name, specifically including COVID relief funds accounting)
- Contingencies Register
- Fee Collection Register
- Register of Donations Received
- Register of Scholarships
- Budget records for the last 5 years

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Josh Dukes

communications.subject: 22-23-19 Dukes
communications.communication:
Good Afternoon,

Please see Kent School District's clarifying questions to your request.


The following financial records for all schools under the authority of the school district:
- Acquaintance Roll (or salary and employment information by any other name)

KSD Comment:  "Acquaintance Roll" is not a term we are familiar with.  We can help present salary information, as we have access to that.  Clarification would be good:

  *   Would they require amounts in aggregate for the year, or individual monthly pay?
     *   What is the objective?  If simply overall pay, we might suggest information in the aggregate.
     *   Does the information need to be broken down by person?
     *   Payroll information can be quite nebulous, with many different categories of pay, deductions, and expenses.  Are they needing that much detail?
  *   What time periods are they requesting?

- The Cash Book (or record of all financial transactions by any other name, specifically including COVID relief funds accounting)

KSD Comment:  "Cash Book" is not a term we are familiar with.  We could provide information on all cash we have received, if this is what is being requested, but this can be very detailed.  Also, is money going out a part of this request?  Clarification would be good:

  *   For money in -- Do they require the information by each party paying us or would they like to see the information by types of cash received (revenue types in the aggregate)?
  *   Revenue in the aggregate would take much less time than information by individuals.
  *   For money out - are they looking for more than just an aggregation?  If detailed transactions were needed, this data would be voluminous.  One can imagine if $450 million is spent each year, how voluminous this might be; i.e., millions of transactions, possibly.
  *   What time periods are they requesting?
  *   COVID relief fund accounting is not too much of a burden, but do they want that down to the transaction level, or in the aggregate?

- Contingencies Register

Are you looking for what obligations we may have in the future to pay, we could interpret this as what we call "encumbrances" or are you looking for what we call "accounts payable".  Accounts payable information is what is owed to vendors and can be provided by vendor name, or in the aggregate, by the type of payment.  Further clarification is definitely needed here.

  *   What time period is being requested?

- Fee Collection Register

We would surmise this would be a published list of what fees we are charging our students for education, is this interpretation correct? Additionally, what time period is being requested?

- Register of Donations Received

Do you want this by person and individual instance, or in the aggregate?  In addition, this could be considered part of the "Cash Book" request.

  *   What time period is being requested?



- Register of Scholarships

Are you interested in what activity there has been for scholarships we manage; i.e., money received and disbursed?

  *   What time period is being requested?

- Budget records for the last 5 years

This is very nebulous and further clarification is needed,  Literally, every record generated from a finance standpoint has to do with budget. Please clarify why type of  budget records you are seeking.



Sincerely,

[cid:image001.png@01D8C778.DE4AB2F0]<https://us-east-2.protection.sophos.com/?d=kent.k12.wa.us&u=aHR0cDovL3d3dy5rZW50LmsxMi53YS51cy8=&e=bGJyYXppbGVAa3Vvdy5vcmc=&h=d6ef8f34c41045f7a123e0f865a2f995&t=bnZCSVU5eEZ0Uy9VSlJ3eG5kU3VUdFBSN3NqWFl3MXBHQ2ZYWVBRMUhVRT0=>
Tyler Inboden (She/Her)
Public Records Officer
Superintendent's Office | Kent School District<https://us-east-2.protection.sophos.com/?d=kent.k12.wa.us&u=aHR0cDovL3d3dy5rZW50LmsxMi53YS51cy8=&e=bGJyYXppbGVAa3Vvdy5vcmc=&h=d6ef8f34c41045f7a123e0f865a2f995&t=bnZCSVU5eEZ0Uy9VSlJ3eG5kU3VUdFBSN3NqWFl3MXBHQ2ZYWVBRMUhVRT0=>

communications.subject: RE: Washington Public Records Act Request: Kent School financial records
communications.communication:
Answers inline

> * Would they require amounts in aggregate for the year, or individual monthly pay?

Individual monthly pay, in CSV, XLS, or other tabular format if export is required. If I have a tabular format I can aggregate and group as needed.

> * Does the information need to be broken down by person?

Yes.

> * Payroll information can be quite nebulous, with many different categories of pay, deductions, and expenses. Are they needing that much detail?

Yes.

> * What time periods are they requesting?

I would like 5 years, but I will accept 2 years if there is a significant increase in difficulty to fulfill a request going back that far.


> KSD Comment: "Cash Book" is not a term we are familiar with. We could provide information on all cash we have received, if this is what is being requested, but this can be very detailed.

Perfect. Please provide in a tabular format, CSV, XLS, if export is required. 

> Also, is money going out a part of this request?

Yes.

> * For money in -- Do they require the information by each party paying us or would they like to see the information by types of cash received (revenue types in the aggregate)?
> * Revenue in the aggregate would take much less time than information by individuals.

Please provide aggregate records.

> * For money out - are they looking for more than just an aggregation? If detailed transactions were needed, this data would be voluminous. One can imagine if $450 million is spent each year, how voluminous this might be; i.e., millions of transactions, possibly.

A few million records is not an especially large data set for me.

> * What time periods are they requesting?

5 years if possible, but I will accept 2 years if 5 years will add a significant delay for the response.

> * COVID relief fund accounting is not too much of a burden, but do they want that down to the transaction level, or in the aggregate?

Transaction.

> Are you looking for what obligations we may have in the future to pay, we could interpret this as what we call "encumbrances" or are you looking for what we call "accounts payable". Accounts payable information is what is owed to vendors and can be provided by vendor name, or in the aggregate, by the type of payment. Further clarification is definitely needed here.

Both at the individual level, in a tabular format if export is required.

* What time period is being requested?

5 years, but I will accept 2 years if 5 years adds a significant delay.

> We would surmise this would be a published list of what fees we are charging our students for education, is this interpretation correct?

Yes.

> Additionally, what time period is being requested?

Same answer as above for the same question.

> - Register of Donations Received

> Do you want this by person and individual instance, or in the aggregate? In addition, this could be considered part of the "Cash Book" request.

If this is included in the "Cash Book" I can pull the records from there.

> * What time period is being requested?

Same answer as above for the same question.

> - Register of Scholarships

> Are you interested in what activity there has been for scholarships we manage; i.e., money received and disbursed?

Yes.

> * What time period is being requested?

See above.

> - Budget records for the last 5 years

> This is very nebulous and further clarification is needed, Literally, every record generated from a finance standpoint has to do with budget. Please clarify why type of budget records you are seeking.

This would be budget planning and reports tracking progress on that plan.

I would also like all statements of work and purchase orders with outside vendors where those exist in digital format.

Good Morning,

This email is in response to your public records request dated September 2, 2022; your request is for the following:


'Budget records for the last 5 years.' Those records can be found here: https://www.kent.k12.wa.us/Page/10019<https://nam02.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.kent.k12.wa.us%2FPage%2F10019&data=05%7C01%7CTyler.Inboden%40kent.k12.wa.us%7C9e92dbfefd624a64ce4508dac2948f4f%7C773029edd6c2480ba5a2281c6d30235e%7C0%7C0%7C638036240570073055%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=151r6HDVbRqnKUG%2FOzntooCtC3ARx35B59z4SWTLGac%3D&reserved=0>

Annual Budgets & Financial Reports. Specifically, the F-195 Budget document for the following available years (7 total):
2021-2022
2020-2021
2019-2020
2018-2019
2017-2018
2016-2017
2015-2015

Additionally, Our server is unable to produce electronic records of "cash out" with the scope provided. (See highlighted text below from when we asked for clarification).  Our system is erroring out and won't produce the report after 3 hours of processing time.

Is it possible to narrow this down to manageable chunks, otherwise, we'd have to go to paper on this item, which would plainly be over 500 pages - we would guess it could be a million pages; i.e., a document for every cash out transaction.


> * For money out - are they looking for more than just an aggregation? If detailed transactions were needed, this data would be voluminous. One can imagine if $450 million is spent each year, how voluminous this might be; i.e., millions of transactions, possibly.

A few million records is not an especially large data set for me.

> * What time periods are they requesting?

5 years if possible, but I will accept 2 years if 5 years will add a significant delay for the response.

However, we can produce a summary of accounts with cash out that can be shared electronically, if that would be sufficient?

At this time we are still processing your request, please expect your next installment on or around November 29th, 2022.

Sincerely,

Please see the attached responsive records to include the expenditure records requested including the Covid data.

Additionally,  we are following up on this: Our server is unable to produce electronic records of "cash out" with the scope provided. (See highlighted text below from when we asked for clarification).  Our system is erroring out and won't produce the report after 3 hours of processing time.

Is it possible to narrow this down to manageable chunks, otherwise, we'd have to go to paper on this item, which would plainly be over 500 pages - we would guess it could be a million pages; i.e., a document for every cash out transaction.


> * For money out - are they looking for more than just an aggregation? If detailed transactions were needed, this data would be voluminous. One can imagine if $450 million is spent each year, how voluminous this might be; i.e., millions of transactions, possibly.

A few million records is not an especially large data set for me.

> * What time periods are they requesting?

5 years if possible, but I will accept 2 years if 5 years will add a significant delay for the response.

However, we can produce a summary of accounts with cash out that can be shared electronically, if that would be sufficient?

At this time we are still processing your request, please expect your next installment on or around December 16th, 2022.

Sincerely,

communications.subject: Louisiana Public Records Law Request: Sheriff Data Collection Request (2021)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Louisiana Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

1. the total number of use of force incidents, separated by type of force and year used in 2021 (for example, information that specifies the number of taser incidents in 2021, baton incidents in 2021, etc.). Please include as part of this a breakdown of how many use of force incidents in each year were related to law enforcement operations and how many were related to correctional/custodial operations.
 
2. the total number of civilian complaints alleging any form of law enforcement misconduct that were reported and the total number sustained in 2021.
 
3. the total number of civilian complaints alleging law enforcement use of excessive force that were reported and the total number sustained in 2021.
 
4. the total number of civilian complaints alleging biased policing or racial profiling that were reported and the total number sustained in 2021.
 
5. the total number of civilian complaints alleging criminal conduct that were reported and the total number sustained in 2021.
 
6. the total number of officer involved shootings in 2021, both fatal and non-fatal.
 
When available, I would appreciate being sent individualized data for each item in this request in spreadsheet format. If individualized data are unavailable, please send information that includes aggregate statistics for the item instead.
 
Note that my requests for civilian complaints are specifically for civilian complaints alleging police misconduct, please do not include complaints filed by one officer/the department against another officer.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Samuel Sinyangwe

Dear Mr. Sinyangwe:

Our law firm represents the East Baton Rouge Sheriff’s Office. As such, I write to respond to your recent request for the following:

1.	the total number of use of force incidents, separated by type of force and year used in 2021 (for example, information that specifies the number of taser incidents in 2021, baton incidents in 2021, etc.). Please include as part of this a breakdown of how many use of force incidents in each year were related to law enforcement operations and how many were related to correctional/custodial operations.
2.	the total number of civilian complaints alleging any form of law enforcement misconduct that were reported and the total number sustained in 2021.
3.	the total number of civilian complaints alleging law enforcement use of excessive force that were reported and the total number sustained in 2021.
4.	the total number of civilian complaints alleging biased policing or racial profiling that were reported and the total number sustained in 2021.
5.	the total number of civilian complaints alleging criminal conduct that were reported and the total number sustained in 2021.
6.	the total number of officer involved shootings in 2021, both fatal and non-fatal.
We are in the process of gathering the requested materials to respond to this request.  However, it will take some time to compile the requested information.  

Please be advised that you must pre-pay for a copy of the materials to be produced, if any are located, in response thereto.  We will contact you once the documents are gathered and the costs are calculated.

October 12, 2022


Samuel Sinyangwe
133564-44065897@requests.muckrock.com

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: BIS letters
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Digital copies of each letter sent to all universities that have been identified by the U.S. Commerce Department Bureau of Industry and Security's Office of Enforcement
Analysis as having an elevated risk profile in conjunction with the bureau's Academic Outreach Initiative. This should encompass at least 20 letters sent to 20 schools. 

I am a reporter researching a story that will inform the public about the bureau's Academic Outreach Initiative, and these documents will facilitate that research.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Kate Kaye

Please include any communications to or from NCIC or WACIC (either email or teletype) about this unidentified person. 

The Agency Case Number for this person is: 85-4584. There is a point of contact for this case, which is one Misty Velotta of the Kirkland Police Department. A PDF copy of the NamUs case file for this unidentified person is attached. Thank you to the Kirkland Police Department for your commitment to transparency, and I look forward to working with you in order to bring this request to a resolution.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

communications.subject: Welcome to the Public Records Center!
communications.communication:
Dear Robert Delaware, 
Thank you for registering with the City of Kirkland Public Records Center. If you submitted the request yourself, congratulations you are done! If the City submitted the request on your behalf, please follow the steps below to log in to your account for the first time:  
  * Click the link to the Public Records Portal (http://www.kirklandwa.gov/depart/Finance_and_Administration/Public_Records/Public_Records_Request/PRRPortal.htm) 
  * Select "View My Public Records Request." 
  * Select "Edit Customer Account Information." 
  * Underneath the submit button, click, "if you don't know or have forgotten your password, click here." 
  * Type in your email address, and click send. 
  * Once you receive the temporary password and log in for the first time, the portal will ask that you change your temporary password. 
Now you can successfully monitor the progress of your request. Should you have any questions, please do not hesitate to contact the City Clerk's Office at (425) 587-3190. 
 
City of Kirkland

communications.subject: Public Records Request :: P039597-122222
communications.communication:
Dear Robert Delaware, 
 
This will acknowledge receipt of your request for access to public records pursuant to the Washington State Public Records Act, Ch. 42.56 RCW. Your request was given the reference number P039597-122222 for tracking purposes. 
 
City staff has begun work on your request and will contact you within five business days, either with the records you have requested, to provide you with an estimate of what date the records will be available for you, or to request a clarification, if necessary.   Note that we may also direct you to the City’s website if the records are available there, notify you that some records may be withheld or redacted, or inform you that there are no responsive records. 
 
If you submitted your request to the Police Department, please call (425) 587-3481 if you have questions. If you submitted a request to any other department, please call the City Clerk’s office at (425) 587-3190. You can also monitor the progress of your request at the link below and you will receive an email when your request has been completed. 
 
Kirkland Public Records

communications.subject: Public Records Request :: P039597-122222
communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 

01/03/2023 

Robert Delaware 
MuckRock News, DEPT MR138195 263 Huntington Ave 
Boston MA 02115 

RE: Full Release of Public Disclosure Request with Redactions: P039597-122222 

Dear Robert Delaware, 
We are writing to update you on the status of your above-referenced records request. The records that have been identified as responsive to your request by the Kirkland Police Department have been uploaded to the City's records portal which you can access by following the steps below:  
  *  (Click Here.) 
  * Select the link to "View My Public Records Requests" 
  * Click “View my requests" 
  * Log in 
  * Select “View Files” and the responsive records will be available to download as a link at the top of the page. 
Please note there are black boxes (redactions) on various pages of the responsive documents. The black box may be small or large depending on the amount of information that is redacted. There may also be multiple redactions on one page. Within the redaction is a "tag" - for example: "03-SSN/DLN." That tag designates the statutory exemption applicable to the redacted information. 
Also provided with these records is an Exemption Key to these tags. This key identifies the basis for the exemption as well as a brief explanation for why the exemption applies to the redacted information. As you review these responsive documents, you can refer to the key to identify the exemption and its applicability. We've attempted to apply clear explanations for the redactions made. In the event you locate documents that contain redactions that you would like further explanation about, please let us know. 
At this time, the Kirkland Police Records Unit believes it has fulfilled your request and it has now been closed. 
If staff has misinterpreted any part of your request, please advise as soon as possible, as it is the intent of staff to fully comply with RCW 42.56 in a timely manner.  We refer you to Kirkland Public Records Act (PRA) Rule 160 and RCW 42.56.550 concerning your rights to petition the City to internally review its decision to apply any and all exemptions.  Additionally, you may also submit a new request for these records at a later date at which point the cited exemption may no longer be applicable. 
Should you have any questions please do not hesitate to contact Police Records at (425) 587-3481 or by responding to this email.  Respectfully, 

Kirkland Police Records Staff 

11750 NE 118th Street  •  Kirkland, Washington 98034-7114  •  425.587.3481  • www.kirklandwa.gov (www.kirklandwa.gov)

communications.subject: RE: Open FOIL NY Request From : Sam Mellins
communications.communication:
November 10, 2022

Sam Mellins
MuckRock News, DEPT MR135456
263 Huntington Ave
Boston, MA 02115
Via: 135456-26585838@requests.muckrock.com<mailto:135456-26585838@requests.muckrock.com>

Re: FOIL GAM-22-10-012

Dear Sam Mellins:

This letter acknowledges partial fulfillment of your consolidated FOIL Request, received on October 19, 2022. Specifically, responsive records regarding your request for "all problem gaming plans submitted by mobile sports wagering operators" are included online within the publicly available application materials submitted by Operators to the Commission<https://www.gaming.ny.gov/pdf/Procurement/RFA%20Mobile%20Sports%20Wagering%20Application%20Licensee2.pdf>. This includes materials from Applicants who were ultimately selected for licensure as well as those entities that applied but were not selected. For your convenience, we have uploaded 32 responsive records from the applications that include language addressing the issue of responsible gaming/problem gambling via the Muckrock online portal. We have also included the report of the evaluation committee that reviewed each application.

Portions of the responsive records are exempt from disclosure pursuant to:

·       Public Officers Law ("POL") § 87(2)(b) because "disclosure would constitute an unwarranted invasion of personal privacy under the provisions of POL § 89(2)."

·       POL § 87(2)(d) because they contain "trade secrets or are submitted to an agency by a commercial enterprise or derived from information obtained from commercial enterprise and which if disclosed, would cause substantial injury to the competitive position of the subject enterprise."

·       POL § 87(2)(g) because they are "inter-agency or intra-agency materials which are not: statistical or factual tabulations or data; instructions to staff that affect the public; final agency policy or determinations; or external audits including but not limited to audits performed by the comptroller and the federal government."

Pursuant to POL § 89(4)(a) you have 30 days to submit a written appeal of this determination to:

Gaming Commission FOIL Appeals Officer
PO Box 7500
Schenectady, NY 12301-7500
FOIL.Requests@gaming.ny.gov<mailto:FOIL.Requests@gaming.ny.gov>

Regarding the remaining components of your request:


·       The three most recent budget forecasts prepared by the office of the executive director

o   The Commission continues to research this request and will respond by November 28, 2022.

·       Emails exchanged between Gaming Commission staff and any email addresses including the domain nyproblemgambling.org since January 1, 2022.

o   The Commission continues to research this request and will respond by November 28, 2022.

·       The most recent analysis prepared by the gaming commission on the impact of mobile sports betting on problem gambling in New York

o   The Commission has no responsive records to this request. The New York State Office of Addiction Services and Supports (OASAS)<https://oasas.ny.gov/> is the executive state agency responsible for problem gambling education, treatment and services.

·       The most recent analysis prepared by the gaming commission on demographics in New York disproportionately impacted by problem gambling related to mobile sports betting.

o   The Commission has no responsive records to this request. The New York State Office of Addiction Services and Supports (OASAS)<https://oasas.ny.gov/> is the executive state agency responsible for problem gambling education, treatment and services.

Sincerely,
Lee Park
Records Access Officer

Accordingly, my request should be granted.

Thank you,
Sam Mellins

title: Automated License Plate Readers (Oakland Police Department)

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Automated License Plate Readers (Oakland Police Department)
communications.communication:
Dear Custodian of Records:

This letter constitutes a request under the California Public Records Act ("CPRA") from the Electronic Frontier Foundation, submitted with the assistance of MuckRock News. 

We request the following records related to Automated License Plate Readers ("ALPRs") and your law enforcement agency ("Agency").

Part A - Information related to ALPR data sharing.

A1. The names of agencies and organizations with which the Agency shares ALPR data;
A2. The names of agencies and organizations from which the Agency receives ALPR data;
A3. The names of agencies and organizations with which the Agency shares “hot list” information;
A4. The names of agencies and organizations from which the Agency receives “hot list” information.
The information requested in items A1-A4 is readily available for extraction through the ALPR software you use. For example, with Vigilant Solutions/Motorola Solutions, this data can be exported easily using the Data Sharing Report function. With Flock Safety, this information is available through the transparency portal function. Other software, such as BOSS, has similar functionality.  

Most agencies have encountered little difficulty in providing this information (see below). In a small number of cases, an agency has interpreted items A1-A4 as requesting the creation of a record that does not exist. We disagree: this data is maintained by your software, can be exported through software your agency has already purchased, and is therefore subject to CPRA. 

However, should you disagree, you may alternatively produce the following records:  

A5. All agreements, memoranda of understanding, requests, or other certifying documents that external agencies have signed to comply with Sec 1798.90.52(b) for accessing your agency's ALPR data. These documents are also often required under the "Releasing ALPR Data" subsection of a California law enforcement agency's SB 34 policy. 
A6. All agreements, memoranda of understanding, requests, or other certifying documents  that your agency has signed pursuant to Sec 1798.90.52(b) to access other agencies' ALPR data.
A7. All "records of access" required by Sec. 1798.90.52(a) for the periods January 1, 2021 until the date of processing this request. 

Items A5-A7 are not necessary if your agency provides the information requested in items A1-A4. We feel that items A1-A4 are more focused and would require less labor from your agency to produce. 

Part B - Information Related to Numbers of “Detections” (plate scans) and “Hits” (plate scans that matched to a hotlist)

B1. The aggregate number of "detections" collected during 2021.
B2.  The aggregate number of “hits” during 2021.
B3. The aggregate number of "detections" from January 1, 2022 until the date this request is processed. If your agency has a retention period shorter than 1 year, please provide whatever data is available based on your retention period. For example, most Flock Safety systems may not have this data beyond 30 days. 
B4.  The aggregate number of “hits” from January 1, 2022 until the date this request is processed. If your agency has a retention period shorter than 1 year, please provide whatever data is available based on your retention period.

The information requested in items B1-B4 is readily available through the ALPR software you use. For example, with Vigilant Solutions/Motorola Solutions, this data can be exported easily using the Hit Ratio Report function. With Flock Safety, this information  is available through the transparency portal function. Other software, such as BOSS, has similar functionality.  As noted above, this information exists within your system and can be easily exported with existing software.

Part C - Assistance, Description, and Recommendations. 

We make the following requests under section 6253.1 of the California Public Records Act

C1. A description of  the information technology and physical location in which the records exist.
C2. Assist us identifying records and information that will help the public understand how ALPR data and hotlists are shared, how much data is collected year-to-year, and how much of that data matches a hot list; and 
C3. Provide suggestions for overcoming any practical basis for denying access to the information sought.

Please note that more than 80 California law enforcement agencies have provided the information requested in Parts A1-A4 and B1-B4 in previous years. For your reference we have included a list below with the names of the agencies that have historically provided these records. 

American Canyon Police Department
Auburn Police Department
Bakersfield Police Department
Beaumont Police Department
Bell Gardens Police Department
Bell Police Department
Belvedere Police Department
Beverly Hills Police Department
Brawley Police Department
Brentwood Police Department

CSU Fullerton Police Department
Cypress Police Department
El Segundo Police Department
Fairfield Police Department
Folsom Police Department
Fontana Police Department
Fresno Police Department
Fullerton Police Department
Galt Police Department
Garden Grove Police Department
Gardena Police Department
Glendale Police Department
Hemet Police Department
Hermosa Beach Police Department
Imperial Police Department
Irvine Police Department
La Habra Police Department
La Mesa Police Department
La Verne Police Department
Laguna Beach Police Department
Livermore Police Department
Lodi Police Department
Long Beach Police Department
Marin County Sheriff's Office
Martinez Police Department
Merced Police Department
Mill Valley Police Department
Modesto Police Department
Monterey Park Police Department
Newport Beach Police Department
Oakley Police Department
Orange County Sheriff's Office
Orange Police Department
Palm Springs Police Department
Palos Verdes Estates Police
Pasadena Police Department
Pleasant Hill Police Department
Pomona Police Department
Redlands Police Department
Redondo Beach Police Department
Ripon Police Department
Roseville Police Department
Salinas Police Department
San Bernardino County Sheriff's Office
San Diego County Sheriff's Office
San Diego Police Department
San Mateo County Sheriff's Office
Sausalito Police Department
Simi Valley Police Department
Stanislaus County Sheriff's Office
Stockton Police Department
Tiburon Police Department
Torrance Police Department
Tracy Police Department
Tustin Police Department
West Sacramento Police Department
Westminster Police Department
Woodland Police Department
Yolo County Sheriff's Office
(This URL links to a dataset with links to the records: https://www.eff.org/document/data-driven-2-california-dragnet-data-set ) 

CPRA requires you to undertake reasonable efforts to locate responsive records and to work in good faith with requesters to respond to their request. See CYAC v. City of National City, 220 Cal.App.4th 1385, 1430 (2013). Thus under the CPRA you are obligated to conduct a reasonable search and cannot deny a request merely because it might generate a large volume of records. 

We ask that you please respond to this request within 10 days either by providing all the requested records or by providing a written response setting forth the legal authority on which you rely in withholding or redacting any document, as well as stating when documents will be made available. Should you choose to withhold or reject this request, we ask that you provide an explanation of why your agency is responding differently compared to the many others that have complied with our request. 

We also request that any records maintained in an electronic format be provided in that same format (such as a PDF, CSV or XLS file), to avoid copying costs.

However, should you be unable to do so, EFF will reimburse you for the direct costs of copying these records (if you elect to charge for copying) plus postage. If you anticipate that these costs will exceed $25.00, or that the time needed to copy the records will delay their release, please contact me so that I can arrange to inspect the documents or decide which documents I wish to have copied. Please also provide an invoice and a cost breakdown of the fee estimate. If the fees are less than $25.00, please copy and send the records and invoice as soon as possible, and we will promptly pay the required costs.

Thank you for your consideration of this request. If you have any questions or concerns, or if I can provide any clarification that will help identify responsive documents or focus this request, please do not hesitate to contact me at (415) 436-9333 x151 or dm@eff.org. You may also mail correspondence to the Electronic Frontier Foundation, 815 Eddy. St. San Francisco, CA, 94109.
                                               
Sincerely,
 
 
Dave Maass
Director of Investigations
Electronic Frontier Foundation

title: Russian Targeting of Election Infrastructure During the 2016 Election (Federal Bureau of Investigation)

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Russian Targeting of Election Infrastructure During the 2016 Election (Federal Bureau of Investigation)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records relating to or mentioning Russian Targeting of Election Infrastructure During the 2016 Election, including but not limited to emails, memos, drafts, assessments, communications with local and state officials, as well as communications with, briefings for and reports to Congress.

I am a member of the news media and request classification as such. I am freelance writer who has previously written about the government and its activities for MuckRock, Motherboard, Unicorn Riot, AND Magazine and Glomar Disclosure. My articles have been widely read, with some reaching over 100,000 readers. My work has been further discussed in outlets including the New York Times, the Washington Post, and BBC. As such, as I have a reasonable expectation of publication and my editorial and writing skills are well established. In addition, I discuss and comment on the files online and make them available through the non-profit Internet Archive, disseminating them to a large audience. While my research is not limited to this, a great deal of it, including this, focuses on the activities and attitudes of the government itself. As such, it is not necessary for me to demonstrate the relevance of this particular subject in advance. Additionally, case law states that “proof of the ability to disseminate the released information to a broad cross-section of the public is not required.” Judicial Watch, Inc. v. Dep’t of Justice, 365 F.3d 1108, 1126 (D.C. Cir. 2004); see Carney v. U.S. Dep’t of Justice, 19 F.3d 807, 814-15 (2d Cir. 1994). Further, courts have held that "qualified because it also had “firm” plans to “publish a number of . . . ‘document sets’” concerning United States foreign and national security policy." Under this criteria, as well, I qualify as a member of the news media. Additionally, courts have held that the news media status "focuses on the nature of the requester, not its request. The provision requires that the request be “made by” a representative of the news media. Id. § 552(a)(4)(A)(ii)(II). A newspaper reporter, for example, is a representative of the news media regardless of how much interest there is in the story for which he or she is requesting information." As such, the details of the request itself are moot for the purposes of determining the appropriate fee category. My primary purpose is to inform about government activities by reporting on it and making the raw data available and I therefore request that fees be waived. Per DOJ FOIA guidance, "a requester should be granted a fee waiver if the requested information (1) sheds light on the activities and operations of the government; (2) is likely to contribute significantly to public understanding of those operations and activities; and (3) is not primarily in the commercial interest of the requester." As this FOIA meets all of those requirements (see above regarding the subject and how I will apply the information), a fee waiver is warranted.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.


Sincerely,

Emma Best

Documentation Files

# Non-Individual FOIA Request

Request Information

To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

the police misconduct records for all officers in the Cambridge Police Department for the years 2018 and 2019. I would like to see what action prompted the misconduct and what action was taken against the officer for there misconduct by the department.

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, processed by a representative of the news media/press and is made in the process of news gathering and not for commercial usage.

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

John-Paul DeLuca

communications.subject: Public Records Request :: P220123-020122
communications.communication:
Dear John-Paul
DeLuca: Your
public records request has been received by the City of Cambridge, and is being
processed in accordance with Public Records Law.  Your request was
received in this office on 2/1/2022 and has been given
the reference number P220123-020122 for tracking
purposes. Requests received after hours, on weekends, or on a City of Cambridge Holiday are considered received on the next business day under the Public Records law, regardless of when they are actually received or entered into our system. Please be advised that the Massachusetts Public Records Law does not require a governmental body to create new records, conduct legal research, or answer questions, in order to provide a response to a request. communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Streaming complaints
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

All complaints filed with the FCC about Netflix, Amazon Prime, Hulu, YouTube, HBO Max, Disney Plus, Roku Channel, and Apple TV+  from January 1, 2018 to the date this request is received. Please limit response to complaints are categorized as "TV" or "Internet."

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Tim Cushing

communications.subject: FOIA 2023-138
communications.communication:
Hello Mr. Cushing, this email is in further reference to your recent FOIA request you filed with the FCC seeking copies of complaints about Netflix, Amazon Prime, Hulu, YouTube, HBO Max, Disney Plus, Roku Channel, and Apple TV+ from January 1, 2018 to November 17, 2022 (the date your request was received) using the form types TV or Internet.



Your request produced approximately 5,500+ complaints.   Producing over 5,500+ complaints would put an undue burden on the agency.  You can also reduce the date range of the complaints you are requesting and reduce the scope of your request (by reducing some of the companies you are seeking complaints about).

Complaints are categorized by various issues (i.e. billing, availability, equipment, unwanted calls, indecency, interference, closed captioning, etc.).    Maybe you can also further reduce the scope of your request by narrowing it to one of the various issues.

Please give me a call on 202 418 2869 if you would like to discuss your request for clarification via telephone.  If we don't hear back from you by December 5, 2022, we will assume you are no longer interested in pursuing your FOIA request, therefore, it will be closed.  You may file a new request at any.
Sincerely,

Mike Hennigan
Consumer Policy Division
Consumer & Governmental Affairs Bureau
202-418-2869

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #FCC-2023-000138
communications.communication:
Mr. Hennigan  - 

I left a message for you on November 25th expressing my desire to have the timeframe limited to January 1, 2020-date of request. I have yet to receive any acknowledgement from your agency that this message was received. Please respond if further fixes are needed. 

Thanks,

Tim Cushing 
605-953-9279

Mike Hennigan

title: Hate Crime Data (2010-2020) (Los Angeles Police Department)

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Hate Crime Data (2010-2020) (Los Angeles Police Department)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Information on all hate crimes occuring in the city of jurisdiction from January 1, 2010 to December 31, 2020. The information should include (although not be restricted to) the following: date-of-occurrence (YYYY-MM-DD), time-of-occurrence (HH:MM),  description of crime committed, location information at the finest geographic level available (street address or block),  beat, district, weapon used, bias motivation (e.g., Anti-Black/Anti-Gay/Anti-Transgender), number of suspect(s),  number of victim(s), injuries incurred, suspect(s) race, victim(s) race,  victim(s) sex, suspect(s) sex,, victim(s) age, suspect(s) age. 

Please provide me with these public records in a machine-readable ASCII format, such as a CSV, SQL, TXT, or similar raw file. CSV or SQL files are preferred when available. Please email the responsive records to my email address: michaeltopper@ucsb.edu.

If email transmission is not feasible, I agree to prepay the actual cost of the storage medium on which the responsive records are transmitted, any postage costs incurred. 

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Michael Topper

communications.subject: [External Message Added] City of Los Angeles public records request #22-10337
communications.communication:
City of Los Angeles ************************************************************************ A message was sent to you regarding record request #22-10337: Dear Requester: Thank you for your patience.   We are continuing to review the responsive record, which will be redacted to protect from disclosure confidential information, pursuant to Government Code Sections 6254(f)(3), 6254(k), and 6255, the Penal Code, and the Welfare and Institutions Code Section 827.9.   Furthermore, regarding your request for the injuries incurred, please be advised that the Department does not track or maintain this data in a database. In order to collect the data, the Department would have to take affirmative steps to manually search each report to determine if any records contain the information you have requested. Thus, the Department asserts Government Code Section 6255 of the California Public Records Act, which exempts records where “the public interest served by not disclosing the record clearly outweighs the public interest served by disclosure." The “public interest” provision of Section 6255 includes an exemption where production of the requested information would be unduly burdensome to the public agency involved. Therefore, we are denying this item of your request.   The Department estimates that it will provide you with the responsive, redacted record by or before January 2, 2023.   If you have any questions, please respond to this email. Respectfully,   LAPD Public Records & Subpoena Response Section, CPRA Unit ************************************************************************ Questions about your request? Reply to this email or sign in to contact staff at City of Los Angeles.

Technical support: See our help page

Michael

communications.subject: Your City of Los Angeles public records request #22-10337 has been closed.
communications.communication:
City of Los Angeles ************************************************************************ Record request #22-10337 has been closed and published. The closure reason supplied was: Dear Requester:   Thank you for your patience.   We have completed our review of your request to the Los Angeles Police Department (“LAPD” or “Department”) under the California Public Records Act (Cal. Govt. Code section 6250, et seq., hereinafter the “CPRA” or “Act”) seeking the following:   "Information on all hate crimes occuring in the city of jurisdiction from January 1, 2010 to December 31, 2020. The information should include (although not be restricted to) the following: date-of-occurrence (YYYY-MM-DD), time-of-occurrence (HH:MM), description of crime committed, location information at the finest geographic level available (street address or block), beat, district, weapon used, bias motivation (e.g., Anti-Black/Anti-Gay/Anti-Transgender), number of suspect(s), number of victim(s), injuries incurred, suspect(s) race, victim(s) race, victim(s) sex, suspect(s) sex, victim(s) age, suspect(s) age." [sic]    The Department is cognizant of its responsibilities under the Act. It recognizes the statutory scheme was enacted to maximize citizen access to the workings of government. The Act does not mandate disclosure of all documents within the government’s possession. Rather, by specific exemption and reference to other statutes, the Act recognizes that there are boundaries where the public’s right to access must be balanced against such weighty considerations as the right of privacy, a right of constitutional dimension under California Constitution, Article 1, Section 1. The law also exempts from disclosure records that are privileged or confidential or otherwise exempt under either express provisions of the Act or pursuant to applicable federal or state law, per California Government Code Sections 6254(b); 6254(c); 6254(f); 6254(k); and 6255.   A responsive document has been provided to you, pertaining to hate crime data from January 1, 2010 to December 31, 2020, including column fields for date and time of occurrence, report number ("DR_NBR"), area, reporting district, description of crime committed, bias motivation, weapon used, party (suspect, victim, arrestee, or involved party), party sequence (the ordinal number of suspect(s) and victim(s) for each incident), and the suspects' and victims' sex, descent (which includes race), and ages. For the requested location information, you may cross-reference the provided report numbers ("DR_NBR") in Column D of the responsive document with the crime data publicly available on the City's Open Data portal. By doing so, this eliminates the need to review each individual incident location for confidentiality and privacy exemptions; therefore, no redactions were necessary. Open Data may be accessed at the following links:   City of LA Crime Data from 2010 to 2019: https://click.pstmrk.it/2tsm/data.lacity.org%2FPublic-Safety%2FCrime-Data-from-2010-to-2019%2F63jg-8b9z/BslxBDYN/DbEk/nT4J0d7bs9/cmVxdWVzdGVyX3JlcXVlc3RfY2xvc2Vk   City of LA Crime Data from 2020 to Present: https://click.pstmrk.it/2tsm/data.lacity.org%2FPublic-Safety%2FCrime-Data-from-2020-to-Present%2F2nrs-mtv8/B8lxBDYN/DbEk/HaDrkNE_bk/cmVxdWVzdGVyX3JlcXVlc3RfY2xvc2Vk   The location information in Open Data has already been reviewed for public release.   Within each link above, data can be viewed by clicking "View Data."   Within each Dataset, the Filter function can be used to filter for the reporting number (DR_NO) and MO Codes (Mocodes).    For example, the following filter may be used to ascertain location information from January 1, 2010 through December 31, 2019:    Add a New Filter Condition, from the drop-down select: DR_NO -> contains ·      [DR_NBR] from the responsive document provided (Column D). Confirm the small box to the left of the search term box is checked.   In the alternative, you may also filter by MO Code (0903 & 0921): Add a New Filter Condition, from the drop-down select: Mocodes -> contains ·      [0903] or ·      [0921] Confirm the small box to the left of the search term box is checked. You may download the datasets via the "Export" function for easier cross-referencing. A manual for deciphering codes used in the dataset has been provided to you, titled "CCADMANUAL2019_121819.pdf."   If you have any questions, please respond to this email.   Respectfully,   LAPD Public Records & Subpoena Response Section, CPRA Unit ************************************************************************ Questions about your request? Reply to this email or sign in to contact staff at City of Los Angeles.

Technical support: See our help page

communications.subject: Ohio Open Records Law Request: Student Surveys
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Ohio Open Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

All surveys given to students at the start of the school year for the years:

2018, 2019, 2020, 2021

With aggregated student responses for those years as well as free text fields. 

Please redact anything that might identify a student or parent individually.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Hal Flak

communications.subject: Re: Ohio Open Records Law Request: Student Surveys
communications.communication:
Hal,


I represent Oakwood City Schools, and am acknowledging receipt of your request pursuant to Ohio's Public Records Act.  Please direct any further communication regarding this request to me.


The Oakwood City School District has only given surveys to students at the start of the 2021-22 school year.  Copies of the surveys are available on the District's website, at the following link:

https://www.oakwoodschools.org/district/departments/educational-services/panorama-surveys

​

Janet Cooper
Of Counsel
BRICKER & ECKLER LLP
312 N. Patterson Blvd., Suite 200
Dayton, OH   45402
jcooper@bricker.com

communications.subject: RE: Ohio Open Records Law Request: Student Surveys
communications.communication:
Thank you for the reply. 

I'm sorry for the confusion:  the surveys I am referring to are administered and created by the district and administered only at the very beginning of the school year prior to students entering class.    

For example,  a survey was administered this year to incoming junior high students online that asked what pronouns the student preferred and if their parents were aware. 

This is different than the Panorama survey that is administered after the start of the school year.

communications.subject: Ohio Open Records Law Request: Student Surveys
communications.communication:
Hal,

Attached are four documents with the questions and responses to the surveys you have requested that were available for students to complete at the beginning of the 2018, 2019, 2020 and 2021 school years.  The survey questions appear at the top of the columns on the first three pages of each of the four documents.

We have redacted personally identifiable student information ([R.C. 149.43(A)(1)(v); R.C. 3319.321; 20 U.S.C. 1232g] including, but not limited to “information, alone or in combination, is linked or linkable to a specific student that would allow a reasonable person in the school community, who does not have personal knowledge of the relevant circumstances, to identify the student with reasonable certainty.”  34 CFR 99.3.

Thank you for your patience regarding this response.  The other outstanding responses will be forthcoming in the next couple of weeks.

Janet Cooper

Janet K. Cooper
Of Counsel
BRICKER & ECKLER LLP
312 N. Patterson Blvd., Suite 200
Dayton, OH   45402
